text: Engagement of the Lewis X antigen ( CD15 ) results in monocyte activation .

text: Using immunological cross-linking to mimic receptor engagement by natural ligands , we now show that CD15 ( Lewis X ) , a monocyte counter - receptor for <extra_id_0> endothelial selectins <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may participate in this response .

We used cytokine production as a readout for monocyte activation and found that CD15 cross-linking induced <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> release from peripheral blood monocytes and cells from the monocytic cell line MM6 .

text: To examine transcriptional regulation of cytokine genes by CD15 engagement , a <extra_id_0> CAT <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> plasmid reporter construct containing <extra_id_0> IL-1 beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter / enhancer sequences was introduced into MM6 .
Subsequent cross-linking of CD15 increased <extra_id_0> CAT <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activity .

CD15 engagement by monoclonal antibody also attenuated <extra_id_0> IL-1 beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcript degradation , demonstrating that signaling via CD15 also had posttranscriptional effects .

Nuclear extracts of anti-CD15 cross-linked cells demonstrated enhanced levels of the transcriptional factor activator protein - 1 , minimally changed nuclear factor-kappa B , and did not affect <extra_id_0> SV40 promoter specific protein-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: We conclude that engagement of CD15 on monocytes results in monocyte activation .

In addition to its well - recognized adhesive role , CD15 may function as an important signaling molecule capable of initiating proinflammatory events in monocytes that come into contact with activated endothelium .
